text: Interactively creates and modifies guide curves.
This node is a tool for creating guide curves for any type of groom.
When using the Guide Groom SOP, make sure to switch to the
radial menu from the top menu bar. This menu lets you quickly switch tools options in the viewport, and is the recommended workflow when using this node.
radial, you can open it by pressing
. This brings up a menu that contains all the
options for the Guide Groom SOP, and reflects the options available in the
dropdown parameter on the node. It’s a quick way to switch between the options on this node.
For example, if you hover your mouse over
, you will see the 4 options available for creating and moving hair. You can either choose one, or navigate back to the previous level by hovering your mouse over the double arrows.
menu that is unique to that mode. For example, the tool options available in
mode are different than the ones available in
This section documents tools available in Guide Groom’s viewport state via the radial menu described above.
Click and drag on the character’s skin and draw out from it to create a hair curve.
Various options are available to modify the drawing behavior. You can draw the entire hair on the character’s skin by enabling
The number of curve segments created is governed by the
to create hairs with a predefined number of segments. Set it to
in order to create more segments for longer curves.
Click on the characters skin to create a hair at that point.
To create many hairs, switch to
To match the shape of surrounding hairs, enable
. With this disabled (or when there are no hairs), the new hair will simply stick out straight from the surface. Length is then controlled by the
will interpolate surrounding hairs but rotate the created hair to match the clicked point’s skin curvature.
Move points around the character skin.
To rotate points with the curvature of the skin, enable
Evens out spacing between hairs. You can control the amount of space using the
Deletes hair until the density matches the
Smooths the shape of curves, removing any high frequency detail.
parameter, the more details are smoothed out.
Clumps together any curves under the cursor. You can do this for the entire curve at once or in a more controlled way using
Sculpt curves by clicking and dragging.
Brush hair while simulating using Vellum physics.
to run the simulation at all times, even while not actively brushing.
to get the effects of physics simulation, with hair floating weightlessly.
Blends (averages) the shapes of hair under the brush.
Attempts to fix skin intersections, where part of the hair dives under the character’s skin.
Use this tool to move curves or individual points using a transform handle.
softly transforms the entire curve or part of it, depending on the
& Drag on the handle to clone curves. You can also clone end points to extend the curve.
After doing this, you may use
to redistribute points evenly along the curve. Or use
to resample to a different segment count.
Brushes hair, rotating from the root.
You can also bend hairs by increasing the
parameter. The shape of the bend is the controlled by the
adjusts length until it matches the
, the hair shape simply scales uniformly.
, hairs are extended or trimmed at the tip.
Changes the orientation of hairs relative to the skin plane.
, hair is rotated until the angle matches the set
Straightens the entire hair shape into a straight line, keeping the original length.
By default, this paints the currently set
onto curves, but you can also change parameters under the
header to add brushed curves to a group instead.
Paint a mask attribute. Other tools use this to limit their effects to the painted region. The mask can be painted per point by enabling
Creating and styling guide hair with Guide Groom
Clears all edits, which resets back to the unmodified input or no geometry at all if no input is connected.
The currently selected elements to be groomed.
The element type of the current selection.
The currently selected tool. The most convenient way to switch between tools is by using the
The thickness of the collision layer around the character’s skin. The Guide Groom SOP prevents curves from passing through this outer layer while you edit them.

The ideal value would be something like 1/10th or 1/100th of the shortest segment length in a groom. Making it much larger would keep curve points at a large distance from the skin. Making it too small would make it easier for curves to end up inside the skin.
Brushing the selection will modify it as a whole, as if all selected curves were clumped together. This makes it easier to preserve the volume of existing clumps while sculpting.

Prevents guides from passing through the character’s skin. It can be useful to turn this off in certain situations. For example, when guide are already stuck inside the skin and you want to move them back out.
Reduces the effect of brushes and tools based on a painted mask. Use the Paint Mask tool to modify this mask.
You’ll also find mask related tools in the

Outputs curves with feather attributes needed to draw as feathers in the
    viewport.
Draw feathers as curves, without any barbs displayed.
Draw feathers with barbs drawn as individual curves.
Sets typical parameter settings needed for working with feathers.

header. The name of orientation attribute is
    set to the standard
The geometry to fetch feather templates from.

The current template to assign to newly created feathers and to use with
    template assignment brushes & tools.

Feathers are assigned a side attribute automatically, either left or right
    depending on their position. Templates will be flipped when they also have
    left or right side set, and their side doesn’t match the curve they're
    assigned to.
Explicitly set the selected feathers to be
Explicitly set the selected feathers to be

feathers. Templates
    assigned to such a feather will never be flipped.
Explicitly set the selected feathers to be "right feathers.
Brush on the character’s surface. When this checkbox is turned off, the brush is in screen space. Most tools work either way, but for some tools such as
, this is always enabled since it only makes sense to plant guides on the surface of the skin.
When this checkbox is turned on, a brush will only affect guides on the cursor’s side of a parting line. This only works when
is turned on, because the brushes' projected skin location is used to determine which side it is on.
The brush radius in pixels, when
The brush radius in Houdini units, when
The strength of the brush effect.
The softness of the brush shape.
When this is non-zero, the brush will be splatted at regular pixel intervals, regardless of how fast you move the cursor. This only works when
Apply operation per point rather than per curve.
The amount the the length of curves is preserved while brushing. Values lower than 1 allow you to modify curve lengths by brushing along the curve.
Values over 0 cause curves to bend more as you brush them, rather than just rotating from the root.
Higher values cause curves to bend more at the tip, lower values cause them to bend more easily at the root.
Rotates curves with the skin curvature as you move them.
Constrain the length of curve segments as you sculpt.
Locks the root in place as you sculpt.
Continuously lifts the curve of the skin as you keep brushing.
Paint the mask values for individual points rather than curves as a whole.
The target angle for the lift tool.
Adjust towards a predetermined absolute length as you brush.
Cuts or extents at the tip, matching the tip direction.
Scales the entire curve, maintaining its shape.
Plants a single curve at the initial click location.
The number of curves to scatter per square unit.
The length of planted curves. This is ignored when
is turned on, as the curves will match the shape and length of nearby guides.
Preserve the orientation of curves relative to the skin.
Plant curves with this number of segments.
Interpolate the shape of nearby guide curves.
When interpolating guides, also maintain the shape’s orientation relative to the character’s skin.
Draw parting line on the character’s skin.
Draw guides on the character’s skin. With this turned off, the first point drawn will sit on the skin, but subsequent points are drawn in the screen plane.
Draw guides with a fixed number of segments.
Create more segments as you draw longer curves, trying to match the
Bend & stretch constraints are computed, but hair doesn’t drop under gravity.
Full physics simulation including dropping under gravity.
Simulate even while not actively brushing
An overall scale applied to the simulation timestep. Greater values slow down the simulation.
Constrains the orientation of the first curve segment.
The strength of the physics brush.
Controls the bend resistance of the simulated hair.
Controls the stretch resistance of the simulated hair.
Sets the rest state to the current simulation state. Once you do this, you can jump back to other tools and back to
, and hair will not drop or settle further.
Resample with a fixed number of segments per curve.
Resample such that a given segment length is matched, placing as many curve segments as necessary.
Adds a new point between two existing points.
Removes all points except root and tip and results in a straight line.
The group of primitives to mirror.
Direction vector of the mirror plane.
Preview the result of the utility.
Bake the result of the current parameter values into the groom.
Delete the mask attribute, clearing any previously painted values.
Add newly created primitives to a group.
The group to add newly created primitives to.
Add the current selection to the
. This does not delete the curves contained in the group.
Hide curves in the current selection.
Set a name attribute on newly created curves.
The name of the name attribute itself. The actual name of curves (i.e. the values of the attribute) are set using the
Newly created primitives will be set to this name when
Selects any primitives whose name matches
Randomly colors primitives based on their name.
A seed value for the randomly generated colors.

is found, use this as the width of the
    output curves.
Set a global width for output curves. This is ignored when

Creates an orient point attribute on newly created curves. Grooming tools
    will update this orient to keep the z-vector of the orientation parallel to
    the curve tangent.
The name of the created orientation attribute. For feathers this should be
Flip values of the up vector attribute specified below.

A global up vector, used when the up vector attribute specified below isn’t
    present.

An skin up vector attribute used to align orientation on newly created
    curves.
This python script will be executed whenever you start a brush stroke.
This python script will be executed whenever the brush is moved during a stroke.
This python script will be executed whenever a brush stroke is finished.

title: Guide Groom
summary: Interactively creates and modifies guide curves.
